responses:
Act 5A, Explosive Act,1884
Persons already in business in respect of certain explosives to carry on such business without licence for a certain period.—Notwithstanding anything in section 5 or in the rules made thereunder where, immediately before the commencement of the Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978 (32 of 1978), any person was carrying on the business of manufacture, sale, transport, import or export of any explosive (for which no licence was required under this Act before its amendment by the Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978, then, such person shall be entitled to continue to carry on such business without licence in respect of such explosive—
(a) for a period of three months from the date of such commencement; or
(b) if before the expiry of the said period of three months, such person has made an application for grant of licence under this Act for such business in such explosive, until the final disposal of his application, whichever is later.]
Under the Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978, businesses dealing with certain explosives were allowed to continue without a license for a specific period.
The Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978, granted a grace period to existing explosive businesses to operate without a license for a limited time.
Before the 1978 amendment, some explosive businesses didn't require a license to operate. This provision allowed them to continue without a license for a defined period.
The Indian Explosives Act's provisions were modified in 1978 to accommodate businesses already involved in the manufacture, sale, transport, import, or export of specific explosives.

Existing explosive businesses, as of the Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978, were given a grace period of three months to continue operations without a license or until their license application was processed, whichever was later.
This provision was introduced to provide a transition period for businesses in the explosives industry to comply with the amended regulations.
If an explosive business applied for a license under the Indian Explosives Act during the grace period, they could continue operating until the final decision on their application.
intents.context: This section discusses the provisions of the Indian Explosives (Amendment) Act, 1978, which allowed existing businesses dealing with certain explosives to continue their operations without a license for a specified period. responses:
The penalties for contravening the rules made under section 5 or the conditions of a license are as follows:
	(a) Manufacturing, importing, or exporting any explosive in violation of the rules or license conditions can lead to imprisonment for up to three years, a fine of up to five thousand rupees, or both.
	(b) Possessing, using, selling, or transporting any explosive in contravention of the rules or license conditions can result in imprisonment for up to two years, a fine of up to three thousand rupees, or both.
	c) In other cases of contravention, a fine of up to one thousand rupees may be imposed.
(2) Contravening a notification issued under section 6, which involves manufacturing, possessing, or importing explosives, can lead to imprisonment for up to three years, a fine of up to five thousand rupees, or both. In the case of importation by water or air, the owner and master of the vessel or aircraft may each face a fine of up to five thousand rupees unless they can provide a reasonable excuse
(3) Various penalties apply for different offenses:
	a) For manufacturing, selling, transporting, importing, exporting, or possessing explosives in contravention of the provisions of clause (a) of section 6A, imprisonment for up to three years, a fine, or both can be imposed
	b) Selling, delivering, or despatching explosives in contravention of the provisions of clause (b) of section 6A can lead to imprisonment for up to three years, a fine, or both.
c) Failing to give notice of any accident in contravention of the provisions of section 8 can result in a fine of up to five hundred rupees. If the accident leads to loss of human life, imprisonment for up to three months, a fine, or both may be imposed.
intents.context: This section outlines the penalties and consequences for various offenses related to explosives under the Explosives Act. It covers contraventions of rules, license conditions, notifications, and provisions related to accidents.
